You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 633, 212, 647]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 649, 728, 680]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[712, 710, 905, 838]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 102, 735, 118]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 164, 468, 180]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 103, 702, 120]]<|/det|>
<pre>2 In this experiment, you will investigate the behaviour of paper on water.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 590, 149]]<|/det|>
<pre>You have been provided with two sheets of tracing paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 184, 179]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 163, 917, 212]]<|/det|>
\(\cdot\) On one of the sheets of tracing paper, draw two identical rectangles as shown in Fig. 2.1 where \(c=4.0 \text { cm}\) and \(d=6.0 \text { cm}\). The orientation of the rectangles must be as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 227, 184, 243]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 227, 676, 243]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 254, 790, 470]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[464, 483, 532, 499]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 514, 544, 530]]<|/det|>
<pre>\(\cdot\) Use the scissors to cut out the rectangles.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 544, 666, 560]]<|/det|>
<pre>\(\cdot\) Take measurements to determine the average value of \(d\).  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 672, 917, 689]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
\(\bullet\) When A is placed flat on the surface of the water in one of the bowls, the shape will curl up as shown in Fig. 2.2. Two edges of the paper will curl and then meet.
